title: James Blunt asks viewers for a kidney as he reveals his father needs a transplant
text:
James Blunt has made a plea for a kidney donor for his unwell father after revealing he isn't a match during an appearance on Good Morning Britain on Wednesday.

The singer, 45, asked host Kate Garraway what her blood type was during their interview as he admitted that his dad Charles needed an organ transplant.

He said: 'I've come on here to ask you what blood group you are. Some things have been going on in my life that I needed to write about. My father has not been very well actually.'

'He needs a new kidney. And he's a kidney donor. And I've come on here to ask you what blood group you are. If you are an O-positive I'll take it off you. James added: 'And I'm not a match.'

The You're Beautiful hitmaker revealed that he has written a song called Monsters on his new album Once Upon A Mind which details how he feels about his father and his diagnosis.

James said: 'Really that has been an amazing moment. Because when you realise your father's mortality it's a great opportunity to say the things I'd like to say to him.

'So I have written a song called Monsters for him. It says I'm not your son, you're not my father, we are just two grown men saying goodbye.'

His father Colonel Charles Blount, a former cavalry officer, has been diagnosed with stage 4 chronic kidney disease.

During the interview James revealed that his album wasn't 'all misery' and detailed the other meanings behind his songs, including his wife and kids.

He said: 'I've come on here to ask you what blood group you are. Some things have been going on in my life that I needed to write about. My father has not been very well actually'

He said: 'But it's not all misery, I have children so wrote songs about them . I go away on tour a lot and leave my wife to pick up the pieces of our family, so there's songs for her too.'

As well as going on tour, James has bought and is in the process of refurbishing a pub in Chelsea called The Fox and Pheasant.

When quizzed on whether his wife is annoyed that he's come off tour and bought a pub, he joked: 'No we're both alcoholics, so it worked well! It’s the fox and pheasant in Chelsea. I'm heavily involved in the refurb!

'People ask where to and I say let’s go to my pub. We do play music, but we generally stay away from mine until five to midnight when we want everyone to leave.'

He added: 'I take the micky out of myself a lot, but I take music v seriously. I got into music and it helps me say things I couldn't say otherwise. It's wonderful to say these things to the people I care about.'
